questions.text: Which of the following muscles contributes to forming both Petit’s triangle and the triangle of auscultation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Latissimus dorsi

Explanation:

 

The latissimus dorsi muscle contributes to the inferior border of the triangle of auscultation and posteriorly in Petit’s triangle.

 

Triangle of auscultation

Petit’s triangle

Description

The triangle of auscultation is a small gap in the musculature on the back of the thorax present near the inferior angle of the scapula.

Also known as the inferior lumbar triangle.

Borders and contents
  • Superiorly by trapezius muscle (Option D)
  • Inferiorly by latissimus dorsi
  • Laterally by the medial border of scapula
  • The floor has the 6th and 7th ribs and the sixth intercostal space
  • Part of the rhomboid major muscle is exposed in the triangle(Option C)
  • Posteriorly by latissimus dorsi
  • Anteriorly by the posterior border of the external oblique
  • The iliac crest inferiorly forms the base
  • Floor has internal oblique muscle (Option B)
     

Significance

  • The apex of the lower lobe of the lung is found deep to it. When the scapulae move anteriorly (arms folded and trunk flexed), the triangle expands, allowing clear auscultation
  • On the left side, the cardiac orifice of the stomach lies deep, previously used to detect esophageal tumors by auscultating swallowed liquids.
  • A collection of pus from the abdomen may show up here.
  • Site of lumbar hernia.
    M/c site for lumbar hernia: Superior lumbar triangle (Grynfeltt) > Inferior lumbar triangle (Petit)
  • Detaching the fascia from the iliac crest enables access to the retroperitoneal space.

questions.text:
All of the following statements about the atlantooccipital joint is/are true except:

1. Allows for flexion and extension of the head

2. It is a synovial condyloid joint

3. Primarily responsible for lateral bending of the head

4. Formed by the articulation between the occipital condyles and the superior articular facets of the atlas

5. It facilitates rotational movement of the head
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 3 and 5

 

Explanation:

  • While the atlanto-occipital joint allows some lateral bending, it is not the primary joint responsible for this movement.
  • Lateral bending of the head is more significantly facilitated by the atlantoaxial joint (between the atlas and axis, C1 and C2) and the cervical spine below.
  • The atlantoaxial joint allows for rotational movements and contributes to lateral flexion.

Atlanto-Occipital Joint

The atlanto-occipital joint is a synovial joint formed between the atlas (C1) and the occipital bone of the skull. Here are key features:

 

Structure: This joint consists of the superior articular facets of the atlas, which articulate with the occipital condyles of the skull.


Function: It primarily allows for nodding movements (flexion and extension), often described as "yes" movements.

Anatomy:

  • The odontoid process (or dens) is a peg-like structure that projects from the body of the axis (C2).
  • It is crucial for the stability and functionality of the cervical spine.
  • The odontoid process is held in place by the transverse ligament of the atlas, which prevents excessive backward movement of the atlas relative to the dens.
  • In the case of fusion, it can be assumed that the body of C1 and C2 may appear fused if there are pathological changes or congenital anomalies.

Atlanto-Axial Joint

 

The atlantoaxial joint is another synovial joint located between the atlas (C1) and axis (C2), and it has specific characteristics:

Structure: This joint consists of the dens of the axis fitting into the anterior arch of the atlas.

Function: It primarily facilitates rotational movements of the head, allowing for the "no" movement.

Anatomy:

  • The atlantoaxial joint is classified as a pivot or trochoid joint, enabling rotational movement around the central axis formed by the dens.
  • The transverse ligament again plays a key role by stabilizing the odontoid process and allowing for controlled rotation of the skull and atlas around the dens.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant with suspected meningitis is scheduled for a lumbar puncture. Which of the following statements about lumbar puncture in infants is incorrect?

choices.text: Procedure is typically done at the L3-L4 intervertebral space.
Procedure is preferably performed under ultrasound guidance.
Supracristal plane corresponds to the L4-L5 vertebral level.
Depth to the subarachnoid space is approximately 1.4 cm in neonates.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Supracristal plane corresponds to the L4-L5 vertebral level.

Explanation:

In infants, the supracristal plane intersects the vertebral column at L3-L4, not L4-L5.

Lumbar Puncture:

Aspect

Adults

Neonates and infants

Spinal Cord Termination

Terminates at the level of L1-L2.

Terminates between L1 and L3 in neonates.

Conus Medullaris Location

Around the L1 and L2 lumbar vertebra and can sometimes be lower.

Commonly at the lower third of L1 vertebral body (range: lower third of T12 to L2/L3 intervertebral disc).

Supracristal Plane
  • A line between the highest points of the iliac crests intersects the vertebral column around L4 or the L4/L5 intervertebral disc; this may vary from the L2/L3 to L5/S1 level.
  • In most adults, the plane intersects the vertebral column inferior to the termination of the spinal cord.

Intersects the vertebral column at L3-L4 level in children. It may vary from L2/L3 to L5/S1 interspinous space. (Option C)

Ultrasound Guidance

Not routinely used.

May be preferable to avoid overlap between the supracristal plane and the termination of the spinal cord. (Option B)

Positioning
  • Patients can be seated or lying on their side (lateral decubitus) on a firm, flat surface.
  • Flex the lumbar spine to separate the vertebral spines maximally and expose the ligamentum flavum.

Infants should be positioned to maximize convex curvature to the lumbar spine, either lying or sitting.

 

Needle Insertion

Insert the needle between the spines of L3 and L4 or L4 and L5, and anesthetize the skin and soft tissues.
  • Performed between spinous processes of either L3 and L4 or L4 and L5, using a trocar needle and into subarachnoid space below the level of conus medullaris. (Option A)
  • Depth to Subarachnoid Space: Approximately 1.4 cm in neonates, increasing with age. (Option D)

Needle Puncturing

Needle Path

Technique
  • Lumbar puncture needle inserted in the midline or just to one side.
  • Angle the needle in the horizontal and sagittal planes to pierce the ligamentum flavum in or near the midline.
  • Slight loss of resistance as the needle enters the epidural space.
  • Careful advancement to pierce the dura and arachnoid to release CSF.

questions.text:
{{caption_text}}



 

Based on the image, which of the following structures is primarily responsible for facilitating the described movement of the head?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dens (Odontoid process) of C2

 

Explanation:

  • The dens (odontoid process) of C2 is the key structure facilitating head rotation.
  • It projects upward from the axis and fits into the atlas (C1), allowing the atlas and skull to rotate around it.
  • This pivot mechanism enables the characteristic side-to-side movement of the head.
 

C1 Vertebra (Atlas)

C2 Vertebra (Axis)
 

Body
  • Lacks a traditional vertebral body.
  • Consists of an anterior and posterior arch.

Prominent body with a unique projection called the odontoid process (dens).

Odontoid process: Bony projection that fits into the atlas ring, allowing for rotational movement of the head and neck.

Spine

Lacks spine

The spine is massive with a bifid tip

Superior Articular Facets

Articulate with the occipital condyles of the skull (atlantooccipital joint)

Articulate with the inferior facets of the atlas (atlantoaxial joint); oriented to permit head rotation.

Inferior Articular Facets

Articulates with C2 (atlantoaxial joint)

Articulates with C3

Transverse process
  • Long transverse process.
  • Has anterior and posterior tubercles for ligament and muscle attachments.
  • Small transverse processes.
  • Lacks anterior tubercle.

Transverse Foramen

Contains a transverse foramen for the passage of the vertebral artery

Role and Movement

Supports the skull; allows nodding movements (flexion and extension) of the head.

Yes movement

Crucial for head rotation; the dens serves as the central pivot point.

No movement

Special Note

Distinct for lacking a vertebral body and spinous process.

Provides stability and acts as the primary pivot for head rotation.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): There are 8 cervical spinal nerves despite there being only 7 cervical vertebrae.
Reason (R): The first cervical nerve exits above the first cervical vertebra, and the remaining nerves exit below their corresponding vertebrae.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The Assertion is correct, but the Reason is incorrect
The Assertion is incorrect, but the Reason is correct

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.

Explanation:

  • The human cervical spine has 8 cervical spinal nerves but only 7 cervical vertebrae.
  • The first cervical nerve exits above the first cervical vertebra, and each subsequent nerve exits below the corresponding vertebra, which accounts for the presence of 8 cervical nerves despite having only 7 cervical vertebrae.

Regions

Number of Vertebrae

Spinal Nerves (Pairs)

Cervical

7

8

Thoracic

12

12

Lumbar

5

5

Sacral

5

5

Coccygeal

4 (varies)

1

Total

33 vertebrae

31 pairs

questions.text: An anatomy professor presents an image of the back region and asks to identify the nerve innervation of muscle marked in green?

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Dorsal scapular nerve

 

Explanation:

  • The muscle marked in above image is Levator scapulae, which is innervated by dorsal scapular nerve.

Muscle

Muscle connecting

Origin

Insertion

Action

Nerve supply

Trapezius

Vertebral column to scapula

Thoracic vertebrae

Spines of cervical and lateral 1/3 of clavicle +

acromion and spine of scapula

Rotation of the scapula during abduction of the humerus overhead.

It is made up of 3 fibers:

1- Middle fibres: Retract scapula

2- Upper fibres: Elevate the scapula.

3- Lower fibres: Depress scapula.

Accessory nerve

(11th cranial nerve)

Rhomboid

major & minor

Vertebral column to scapula

Thoracic spines

Medial border of the scapula.

Retract scapula.

Dorsal scapular nerve.

Levator scapulae

Vertebral column to scapula

Cervical transverse processes

Medial border of the scapula.

Elevates scapula

Dorsal scapular nerve.

Latissimus dorsi

Vertebral column to

Humerus

Spines of thoracic vertebrae

Bicipital groove of the humerus.

Extension, adduction & medial rotation of humerus.

Thoracodorsal nerve

questions.text: By the end of fetal development, at which vertebral level does the spinal cord terminate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Upper border of L3

 

Explanation:

By the end of fetal development, the spinal cord terminates at the upper border of the L3 vertebra.

 

 

Fetus:

  • Initially, the spinal cord and vertebral column are the same length.
  • The vertebral column grows faster, causing the spinal cord to ascend.
  • Ascent milestones:
    • Begins around 9 weeks.
    • Reaches the last sacral vertebra by 12 weeks.
    • Attains the lower border of S1 by 15 weeks.
    • Reaches the lower border of L4 at 6 months.
    • Reaches the lower border of L3 at full term. (Option C)

 

Child:

  • The spinal cord terminates at the upper border of L3.

 

Adult:

  • The spinal cord ends at the lower border of L1 (Option A) known as the conus medullaris.
  • Below this level, the vertebral canal contains the cauda equina.

 

Clinical significance:

  • Lumbar puncture in adults must be done below L2 at the level of L3-L4 or L4-L5 laminae as this avoids injury to the spinal cord.
  • In children, it is done at the lower level of L4.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis, underwent MRI which showed tectorial membrane thickening. This structure is derived from which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Posterior longitudinal ligament

 

Explanation:

  • The membrana tectoria is a structure in the cervical spine that is part of the ligaments of the spinal cord.
  • It is a continuation of the posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL) in the neck region and plays an important role in stabilizing the cervical spine
  • It lies in the upper part of the cervical spine on the posterior surface of vertebral body, specifically in the area around the atlas (C1) and axis (C2), just below the level of the foramen magnum in the skull.
  • Above the level of axis , the posterior longitudinal ligament continues as membrana tectoria.
  • It extends from the axis to foramen magnum.

questions.text:
Match the right options.

 


	
		
			
			a
			
			
			Spine of scapula
			
			
			i
			
			
			T2
			
		
		
			
			b
			
			
			Highest point of iliac crest
			
			
			ii
			
			
			T3
			
		
		
			
			c
			
			
			Superior angle of scapula
			
			
			iii
			
			
			T7
			
		
		
			
			d
			
			
			Inferior angle of scapula
			
			
			iv
			
			
			L4
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii

 

Explanation:

  • The scapula extends from rib 2 to rib 7 with its superior angle palpable over the trapezius and its inferior angle over the latissimus dorsi.
  • These angles are connected to each other by the medial border of the scapula running vertically.
  • The spine of the scapula is easily palpable as it runs subcutaneously.

 

Parts of scapula

Corresponding vertebrae

Spine

T3 (spinous process)

Superior angle

T2

Inferior angle

T7

Other important landmarks

  

Highest point of iliac crest

L4

Posterior-superior iliac spine

S2

questions.text: Which of the following is true about cauda equina?

choices.text: It is comprised of the terminal end of the spinal cord
Ends at L1-L2 vertebra in adults
Surrounded by CSF in the subarachnoid space
The filum terminale begins from the apex of cauda equina

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Surrounded by CSF in the subarachnoid space

Explanation:

The cauda equina is surrounded by the CSF in the subarachnoid space and is a bundle of spinal nerve roots (not the spinal cord's end) that extends into the sacral region surrounded by the filum terminale.


 

 

Cauda Equina

Conus Medullaris

Definition

A bundle of spinal nerve roots resembling a horse's tail (Option A)

The tapered end of the spinal cord

Location

Below the conus medullaris, in the vertebral canal

At the lower end of the spinal cord

Structure

Composed of dorsal and ventral nerve roots from L2 to S5 and Co1

Comprised of the terminal end of the spinal cord

Number of Nerve Roots

40 nerve roots (16 lumbar, 20 sacral, 4 coccygeal)

None; terminates without forming new roots

Formation of Spinal Nerves

Dorsal and ventral roots join at intervertebral foramina

Does not contribute to new spinal nerves

Filum Terminale

Surrounds cauda equina

Attached to the apex of conus medullaris (Option D)

Clinical Relevance

Site for lumbar puncture; potential for cauda equina syndrome

Indicates termination of spinal cord; important for anatomical reference

Length

Extends to the sacral region, around 15-20 cm (Option B)

Generally ends at L1-L2 vertebrae in adults

Surrounding Structures

Surrounded by cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space

Encased by pia mater; continuous with filum terminale

Anatomical Changes with Age

Remains relatively constant

Position shifts upward in younger individuals

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with complaints of lower back pain radiating down his left leg, associated with numbness over the top of his foot and difficulty in dorsiflexing his big toe. On examination, he has weakness in the extension of the great toe and decreased sensation along the dorsum of the foot. Reflexes are normal. Based on the symptoms, which vertebral level is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L4-L5

 

Explanation:

 

  • The patient's symptoms suggest nerve root compression, commonly caused by a herniated disc.
  • The key findings in this case include lower back pain radiating down the left leg, numbness over the top of the foot, and weakness in dorsiflexion of the great toe (extensor hallucis longus), without reflex abnormalities.
  • These are classic signs of L5 nerve root involvement.

 

L5 nerve root compression, often due to L4-L5 disc herniation, results in:

  • Weakness in great toe dorsiflexion (extensor hallucis longus).
  • Sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot.
  • Radiating pain down the lateral aspect of leg.


 

Slipped disc:

 

  • A herniated disc, also known as a slipped disc, occurs when the soft center (nucleus pulposus) of a spinal disc pushes through a tear in the tougher exterior (annulus fibrosus) and presses on nearby nerves.
  • Herniated discs most commonly occur in the cervical (neck) and lumbar (lower back) spine. Here's an explanation of herniated discs affecting both the cervical and lumbar regions.

Cervical Slip Disc (Upper Limb Involvement):

  • In the cervical region, the nerves exit above their corresponding vertebrae (except for the C8 nerve).
  • The affected nerve root, in the case of a herniated disc, is typically the one corresponding to the lower vertebra in the pair.

 

Cervical Slip Discs and Affected Nerve Roots

 

Herniated Disc Between

Compressed Nerve Root

Symptoms (Upper Limb)

C4 and C5

C5

Shoulder pain, weakness in deltoid muscle

C5 and C6

C6

Pain in biceps, weakness in wrist extension

C6 and C7

C7

Triceps weakness, difficulty extending the elbow

C7 and T1

C8

Hand weakness, difficulty with finger movements

Lumbar Slip Disc (Lower Limb Involvement)

  • In the lumbar region, the nerves exit below their corresponding vertebrae.
  • Therefore, when a disc herniation occurs between two vertebrae, the nerve root corresponding to the lower vertebra is usually compressed.

 

Lumbar Slip Discs and Affected Nerve Roots

 

Herniated Disc Between

Compressed Nerve Root

Symptoms (Lower Limb)

L3 and L4

L4

Weakness in knee extension, reduced patellar reflex

L4 and L5

L5

Weakness in foot dorsiflexion, difficulty walking

L5 and S1

S1

Pain down the back of the leg, reduced Achilles reflex, foot drop

 

Regional Prevalence:

  • Cervicothoracic (C6-T1): 10% of cases
  • Lumbosacral (L4-S1): 90% of cases
  • Thoracic: Rare

L3-L4 (Option A):

  • Compression at this level typically affects the L4 nerve root, causing weakness in knee extension (quadriceps) and decreased sensation over the medial side of the lower leg.
  • This is not consistent with the patient's symptoms.

 

L5-S1 (Option C):

  • Compression here would affect the S1 nerve root, causing weakness in plantarflexion (gastrocnemius), decreased ankle reflex, and sensory loss along the lateral aspect of the foot.
  • This does not match the patient's findings.

 

T12-L1 (Option D):

  • This is much higher in the vertebral column and would affect muscles and sensations around the lower abdomen and upper thighs, which are unrelated to the symptoms described in this case.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought in for a routine check-up. The parents have noticed a pronounced lumbar curvature since the child began walking. Which of the following best describes this lumbar curvature?

choices.text: Curvature related to increased abdominal weight

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary curvature

 

Explanation:

Lumbar lordosis is a secondary curvature that becomes evident in infancy as the child begins to assume upright posture, stand and walk, contributing to normal posture development.

 

Vertebral Curvature:

  • Vertebral column in adults has 4 curvatures:
    • Cervical lordosis
    • Thoracic kyphosis
    • Lumbar lordosis
    • Sacral kyphosis

  • Types of Vertebral Curvature:

Primary Curvature

Secondary Curvature
  • Developmental.
  • Thoracic and sacral kyphosis (both concave anteriorly) are primary curvatures. (Option A & C)
  • Develop during the fetal period in response to the flexed fetal position.
  • Are in the same direction as the main curvatures of the fetal vertebral column.
  • Retained throughout life due to differences in height between the anterior and posterior parts of the vertebrae.
  • Acquired in relation to the erect human posture.
  • Cervical and lumbar lordosis (both concave posteriorly) are secondary curvatures.
  • Result from extension from the flexed fetal position.
  • Begin to appear during the late fetal period but do not become obvious until infancy (roughly, 1st year).
  • Secondary curvatures are primarily maintained by differences in the thickness between the anterior and posterior parts of the intervertebral (IV) discs.
  • Cervical lordosis becomes evident when an infant begins to raise (extend) the head while prone and to hold the head up while sitting.
  • Lumbar lordosis appears when toddlers (children learning to walk) begin to assume upright posture, standing and walking. It is more pronounced in females. (Option B)

 

  • Functional Importance: Curvatures of the vertebral column enhance flexibility (shock-absorbing resilience), augmenting the passive flexibility provided by the intervertebral (IV) discs.
  • Response to Increased Load: When bearing heavy loads (e.g., carrying a heavy backpack), both the IV discs and curvatures are compressed, increasing the curvature.
  • Impact of Additional Anterior Weight: Carrying weight in front of the body’s normal gravitational axis (e.g., large breasts, obesity, pregnancy, or carrying a child) tends to increase these curvatures. (Option D)

questions.text: A patient has restricted spinal rotation and lateral flexion. Which vertebral structure primarily functions as a lever for these movements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Transverse process

Explanation:

Transverse processes project laterally from the pediculolaminar junctions and serve as levers for muscles and ligaments mainly involved in spinal rotation and lateral flexion.

 

Typical Vertebra

Has a ventral body, dorsal arch with processes, and a vertebral foramen.

Image

Vertebral Body
  • Adjacent vertebral bodies are connected by fibrocartilage discs.
  • Form a flexible, weight-supporting central axis.
  • Transmits even greater forces generated from attached muscles.

Vertebral Arch

  • Consists of pedicles and a broader laminae.
  • Transverse, superior, and inferior articular processes project from the junction of the pedicle and lamina.

Vertebral Foramina
  • Formed by the vertebral arch and body.
  • Contains the spinal cord, meninges and their vessels.

Intervertebral Foramina
  • Located between adjoining vertebrae, near junctions of vertebral bodies and arches.
  • Transmit mixed spinal nerves, small recurrent nerves, and blood and lymphatic vessels.

Spinous Processes

(Option A)
  • Project dorsally from the junction of the lamina.
  • Act as levers for muscles that control posture and active movements (flexion/extension, lateral flexion and rotation) of the vertebral column.

Transverse Processes

(Option D)
  • Project laterally from the pediculolaminar junctions.
  • Serve as levers for muscles and ligaments, mainly concerned with rotation and lateral flexion.

Articular Processes

(Option B & C)
  • Superior articular processes project cranially with dorsal facets; inferior articular processes project caudally with ventral facets.
  • They form zygapophysial or facet joints and form part of the posterior boundaries of intervertebral foramina, permitting only limited vertebral movement.

Trabecular Structure
  • Vertebrae are internally composed of trabecular bone with an outer shell of compact bone perforated by vascular foramina.
  • Trabecular interior contains red bone marrow and basivertebral veins.

questions.text:
An anatomy professor presents an image of a vertebra in class and asks the students to identify its type. Which type of vertebra is depicted in the image?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lumbar vertebrae

 

Explanation:

Lumbar vertebrae are characterized by their large size, thick and horizontal spinous processes, and the absence of transverse foramina (which are present in cervical vertebrae) or costal facets (which are found in thoracic vertebrae).

Feature

Cervical Vertebrae (Option A)

Thoracic Vertebrae (Option B)

Lumbar Vertebrae

(Option C)

Image

Size

Small size

Intermediate-size

Large size

Body

Small, broad with a convex anterior surface.

Waisted cylinder; nearly equal transverse and AP dimensions.

Wider transversely

Vertebral Canal

Triangular

Small and circular

Triangular

Pedicles and Laminae

Pedicles: Attach midway between the discal surface of the vertebral body.

Lamina: Thin, slightly curved.

Pedicles: Do not diverge as the vertebral foramen is small and circular

Lamina: Short, thick, and broad.

Pedicles: Short

Laminae: Broad and short.

Spinous Process

Short, bifid with two unequal tubercles.

Slants downward.

Almost horizontal, quadrangular, and thickened along its posterior and inferior borders.

Transverse Process

Composite structure

Large, club-like.

Long, thin.

Superior Articular Facets

Flat and ovoid, directed superoposteriorly.

Directed posteriorly and slightly superolaterally.

Bear vertical concave facets facing posteromedially.

Inferior Articular Facets

Directed mainly anteriorly.

Directed forwards and slightly superomedially.

Have vertical convex articular facets facing anterolaterally.

Special Features

Foramen Transversarium: Transmits the vertebral artery and vein, and a branch from the cervicothoracic ganglion (vertebral nerve) except in the seventh cervical vertebra.

Have lateral costal facets and transverse process facets for rib articulation.

Costal facets and transverse foramina are absent.

Sacral vertebrae (Option D) are not considered individually because they fuse into a single immobile sacrum during adolescence, typically formed from five segments.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient undergoes spinal surgery. Postoperatively, he develops a cerebrospinal fluid leak. Which space is most likely compromised?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) C

 

Explanation:

The subarachnoid space, which contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), is likely compromised after spinal surgery due to potential puncture of the dura or arachnoid.

Epidural Space (Option A)

Subdural Space

Subarachnoid Space
  • Located between the spinal dura mater and the periosteum.
  • Contains:
    • Loose areolar tissue
    • Semiliquid fat
    • Spinal arteries supplying deeper structures
    • Internal vertebral venous plexus.
  • Epidural anesthesia is given here
  • Potential space between the dura and arachnoid mater. (Option B)
  • Contains a thin layer of serous fluid.
  • Allows movement of the dura over the arachnoid.
  • Extends onto spinal nerves and connects with lymphatic spaces.
  • Wide space between pia mater and arachnoid mater.
  • Filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). (Option C)
  • Cushions the brain and spinal cord.
  • Wider in the spinal region, especially below the spinal cord where it encloses the cauda equina.
  • Lumbar punctures are typically performed between L3 & L4 vertebrae.

Periosteal space (Option D) is not a recognized anatomical space for CSF.

questions.text:
A patient undergoes a procedure affecting a delicate, thread-like structure extending from the conus medullaris to the coccyx as marked in the figure. Which of the following statements regarding this structure is correct?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: It is composed mainly of dura mater and contains no nerve fibers
Distal part of it is called the coccygeal ligament.
It does not extend beyond the sacral hiatus
It measures about 50 cm in length

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Distal part of it is called the coccygeal ligament.

 

Explanation:

The marked structure in the given image is the Filum terminale and it consists of 2 parts: filum terminale internum and the distal filum terminale externum, also known as the coccygeal ligament.

Filum terminale is a thread-like extension of the pia mater (Option A) measuring about 20 cm in length. (Option D)

 

  • Location: Extends from the tip of the conus medullaris to the base of the coccyx.
    • Pathway: Pierces the dural tube, traverses the sacral canal and sacral hiatus (Option C) and attaches to the dorsal surface of the first coccygeal vertebra.

  • Segments
    • Filum Terminale Internum: Approximately 15 cm long, located within the dural sac.
    • Filum Terminale Externum: About 5 cm long, situated outside the dura mater, below the second sacral vertebra.
  • Composition:
    • Primarily pia mater, with some nerve fibers from the second and third coccygeal nerves on its outer surface.
    • The central canal of the spinal cord extends into it for about 5 mm.

questions.text: Which of the following spinal segments is located between the cervical enlargement of the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) C5 to T1

 

Explanation:

The cervical enlargement is specifically found in the C5 to T1 spinal segments, providing nerves that form the brachial plexus.

 

Cervical Enlargement

Lumbar Enlargement

Extent

C5 to T1 spinal segments (Option B)

L2 to S3 spinal segments (Option C)

Function

Gives rise to the brachial plexus

Contributes to the lumbar plexus

Corresponding vertebral level

C3 to T1 vertebrae. (Option D)
